title: Mastering Time Management
content:
Plan Your Week Ahead

Use a planner, diary, or digital calendar to schedule your week. Block out study time, assignments, extracurriculars, and even downtime. Having a visual plan helps reduce last-minute stress and keeps you on top of deadlines.

Prioritise with the “To-Do List” Method

Each day, write a short list of 3–5 key tasks you want to complete. Prioritise them by importance and urgency. Ticking off completed items gives a sense of accomplishment and keeps you motivated.

Break Big Tasks into Smaller Steps

Feeling overwhelmed by a big assignment or exam prep? Break it into smaller, manageable steps and tackle one at a time. This makes work feel less daunting and easier to start.

Use the Two-Minute Rule

If a task takes less than two minutes — like replying to an email or filing notes — do it right away. This rule helps clear small tasks quickly so they don’t pile up and distract you from bigger ones.

Set Goals That Motivate You

Create both long-term (term goals) and short-term (weekly goals) to stay focused. Make sure your goals are specific, realistic, and measurable — like "Finish History essay draft by Friday" instead of "Work on essay sometime."

Avoid Multitasking — Focus on One Thing

Switching between tasks actually slows you down and lowers the quality of your work. Give your full attention to one subject or task at a time. You’ll finish faster and remember more too.

Protect Your Downtime

Rest is just as important as study. Schedule regular breaks, sleep, and time to relax or spend with friends and family. A well-rested brain performs better and handles stress more easily.

Review Your Routine Weekly

At the end of each week, take 10 minutes to reflect: What worked? What didn’t? Adjust your schedule and habits accordingly. Small changes over time can lead to big improvements in productivity and balance.
